# Profitability Trends

The banking system continued to record profits in 2022. During the year, the overall pre-tax operating profit of retail banks increased by 19.0% (Figure 7). The improvement in profitability was driven by increases in net interest income (+34%) and income from foreign exchange and derivatives (+72%), though part of the increase was offset by higher provisions for bad and doubtful debts (+151%) and a decrease in fee and commission income (–19%). In a rising interest rate environment, the net interest margin widened from 0.98% in the previous year to 1.31% in 2022 (Figure 8). Increased market volatility during the year also boosted banks’ income from foreign exchange and derivatives business. The increase in provisions for bad and doubtful debts was due to the need to set aside special provisions for new classified loans, while the weak performance of financial markets led to a decrease in fee and commission income. # Balance Sheet Trends

In 2022, the banking system’s balance sheet expanded by 2.5%. The increase in assets was due to the mark-to-market valuation gains on foreign exchange and derivatives positions. Amid external uncertainties and rising interest rates, loan demand weakened during the year. Compared to a 3.8% increase in 2021, total loans decreased by 3.0% in 2022. Loans for use outside Hong Kong fell by 10.2%, trade finance dropped by 13.5%, while loans for use in Hong Kong edged up by 0.9%. Mainland China-related loans, after growing by 3.7% in 2021, declined by 4.4% in 2022.

On the liabilities side of the balance sheet, the banking system continued to record moderate growth in deposits. Total deposits increased by 1.7% in 2022, compared to a 4.6% increase in 2021. As total loans decreased while total deposits increased, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio declined slightly from 71.8% at the end of 2021 to 68.5% at the end of 2022 (Figure 10).

# Capital Adequacy Levels

Banks maintained robust capital positions in 2022. At the end of 2022, the consolidated total capital ratio of locally incorporated authorized institutions stood at 20.1%, compared to 20.2% in the previous year; the Tier 1 capital ratio was 18.1% (Figure 11). The liquidity position of the banking system remained sound, serving as an important pillar amid heightened uncertainties in the macroeconomic environment. The quarterly average liquidity coverage ratio for Category 1 institutions was 162.3% in the fourth quarter of 2022, while the quarterly average liquidity maintenance ratio for Category 2 institutions was 63.2% (Figure 13). # Monetary Stability

With the tightening of monetary policy in the United States, the Hong Kong dollar weakened in 2022, and the weak-side Convertibility Undertaking was triggered 41 times between May and November. Driven by increased trading activity in the local stock market and seasonal year-end funding demand, the Hong Kong dollar began to strengthen in mid-November. Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, Hong Kong interbank offered rates generally tracked the movements of US dollar interbank rates. Due to the continued interest rate hikes in the US, Hong Kong interbank rates gradually rose throughout 2022. Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange and money markets remained stable, with smooth and orderly trading. As the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, the Linked Exchange Rate System has consistently demonstrated a strong ability to withstand external shocks.

# Objective

The primary objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability, that is, to ensure the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, keeping it within the range of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85 per US dollar in the foreign exchange market. This monetary regime mainly adopts a Currency Board System, which requires that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund provide at least 100% backing for the monetary base; any change in the monetary base must be matched by a corresponding change in US dollar reserves, maintaining a 100% link with changes in the monetary base.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:
- Certificates of Indebtedness (providing full backing for banknotes issued by the three note-issuing banks);
- Government-issued circulating notes and coins;
- The aggregate balance of settlement accounts maintained with the HKMA (i.e., the Aggregate Balance); and
- Exchange Fund Bills and Notes issued by the HKMA on behalf of the government.

The HKMA maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through the Automatic Interest Rate Adjustment Mechanism and its firm commitment to honoring the Convertibility Undertaking. When the strong-side (or weak-side) Convertibility Undertaking is triggered, the HKMA, upon banks’ requests, will sell Hong Kong dollars and buy US dollars at HK$7.75 per US dollar (or buy Hong Kong dollars and sell US dollars at HK$7.85 per US dollar), thereby increasing (or decreasing) the Aggregate Balance, causing Hong Kong dollar interest rates to fall (or rise), and thus guiding the exchange rate back to the HK$7.75–7.85 range.

# Review of 2022

# Exchange Rate Stability

Driven by adjustments in the local stock market, market expectations of further US interest rate hikes, and carry trades arising from the negative interest rate spread between Hong Kong interbank rates and LIBOR, the Hong Kong dollar weakened at the beginning of 2022 and remained close to the weak-side Convertibility Undertaking level in subsequent months. The weak-side Convertibility Undertaking was triggered 41 times between May and November. Supported by increased trading activity in the local stock market and seasonal year-end funding demand, the Hong Kong dollar began to strengthen in mid-November (Figure 1). Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange market continued to operate normally throughout 2022.

To meet the ongoing demand from banks for Exchange Fund Bills, the HKMA issued an additional HK$40 billion of Exchange Fund Bills at the beginning of 2022. In addition, between May and November 2022, in accordance with the design of the Linked Exchange Rate System, the HKMA, upon banks’ requests, purchased a total of HK$242.1 billion at the weak-side Convertibility Undertaking rate. The Aggregate Balance decreased from HK$377.5 billion at the end of 2021 to HK$96.3 billion at the end of 2022, reflecting the impact of the additional issuance of Exchange Fund Bills and the triggering of the weak-side Convertibility Undertaking. Meanwhile, the outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Bills and Notes increased slightly from HK$1,148.8 billion to HK$1,200.4 billion during the year. As a result, the sum of the Aggregate Balance and the outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and Notes decreased from HK$1,526.3 billion at the end of 2021 to HK$1,296.7 billion at the end of 2022 (Figure 2). The overall monetary base continued to be fully backed by foreign exchange reserves.

Figure 1: Market Exchange Rate in 2022

Figure 2: Aggregate Balance (before Discount Window activities) and Outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and Notes in 2022

# Money Market

Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, Hong Kong interbank offered rates generally tracked the movements of US dollar interbank rates. As the US continued to raise interest rates in 2022, Hong Kong interbank rates gradually increased (Figure 3). Over the year, overnight, 1-month, and 3-month HIBOR rose by 318, 419, and 473 basis points respectively, reaching 3.23%, 4.35%, and 4.99% at year-end.

In response to the upward adjustment of the US federal funds target range, the Base Rate was raised seven times, by a total of 4.25 percentage points (i.e., 425 basis points), from 0.5% to 4.75% (Figure 3). At the retail level, following the US policy rate hikes, several banks raised their prime lending rates by 12.5 basis points in late September, by a further 25 basis points in early November, and by another 25 basis points in mid-December. Some banks also raised the cap on new mortgage rates based on HIBOR during the year. Overall, the Hong Kong money market continued to operate normally. Discount Window borrowing increased from HK$6.8 billion in 2021 to HK$8.4 billion in 2022.

Figure 3: Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates in 2022

# Linked Exchange Rate System

For nearly 40 years, the Linked Exchange Rate System has been a vital pillar of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating a strong capacity to respond to challenges. Despite the volatile global financial environment in 2022, the Hong Kong dollar’s foreign exchange and money markets continued to operate in an orderly manner, reflecting the robustness and effectiveness of the Linked Exchange Rate System. The government remains firmly committed to maintaining the system. In its 2022 External Sector Report, the International Monetary Fund reiterated that Hong Kong possesses transparent rules, substantial fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, robust financial regulation and supervision, a flexible economy, and a prudent fiscal framework, all of which ensure the credibility of the Linked Exchange Rate System.

A sound banking system is crucial to the normal operation of the Linked Exchange Rate System. Hong Kong’s banking sector continued to function smoothly, with liquidity and capital positions remaining very strong by international standards. To ensure that the banking system is resilient to shocks, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has been closely monitoring banks’ credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as the results of stress tests, and maintains supervision over bank lending.

To enhance the transparency of the Currency Board accounts, since October 1998, a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets has been designated to back the monetary base. The Backing Ratio (i.e., the ratio of backing assets to the monetary base) fluctuated between 109.3% and 111.0% in 2022, without reaching either the upper or lower limits. As of December 31, the ratio stood at 110.1% (see Chart 4). Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, although certain Exchange Fund assets are designated as the backing portfolio, all assets of the Exchange Fund can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The substantial fiscal resources of the Exchange Fund, together with Hong Kong’s robust banking system, provide a strong backing for safeguarding Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

因應最新的香港洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險評估，金管局與銀行透過公私營夥伴合作（包括反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組），鞏固香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集生態圈，以及加強應對騙案。此外，金管局亦與策略夥伴合作，以能更充分了解及有效管理日益複雜的地緣政治環境所帶來的風險及不穩定因素。金管局又透過「反洗錢合規科技實驗室」系列進一步推動業界運用數據及科技，並同時加快金管局在反洗錢工作中採用監管科技的步伐。在國際事務方面，金管局積極參與財務行動特別組織的工作。

在2022年，本地就有關資本充足標準及披露標準等國際監管標準的實施上取得良好進展。此外，金管局亦大力提升業界的軟實力，包括與銀行業合作建立可持續的人才儲備，以及提升現有從業員的技能。年內金管局一直與銀行業緊密合作，改進及精簡監管政策與程序。

金管局亦繼續致力推進在本地及國際層面的工作，以確保香港備有具公信力的處置機制。具體工作包括制定新處置標準；進行地區危機模擬演習，以及在所有具本地系統重要性銀行建立一層新的吸收虧損能力資源，標誌着金管局在提升處置可行性上立下里程碑。

# 目標

金管局的整體目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響銀行體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊及應對危機恢復常態，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。

香港的審慎監管制度並非為確保「零風險」而設。作為其中一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構（以及其他類型機構）的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，有必要制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

金融管理專員亦負責指定及監察某些金融市場基建。金管局監察金融市場基建的目的，是促進有關基建的整體安全及效率、控制系統性風險，以及提高透明度。提升金融市場基建的抗震能力，能保障香港的貨幣與金融體系，避免因金融市場基建運作中斷而可能影響其穩定。

# Stability of the Banking System

Despite uncertainties and challenges in the macroeconomic environment, coupled with abnormal volatility in financial markets, Hong Kong’s banking system remained robust in 2022. During the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also strengthened its supervision of credit and market risk management for authorized institutions. Furthermore, in view of the persistent increase in cyber threats and the accelerating pace of digital transformation in the banking sector, the HKMA worked closely with authorized institutions to enhance their operational resilience and cyber defense capabilities.

In terms of conduct supervision, the HKMA strengthened consumer protection for "Buy Now, Pay Later" products and provided an additional payment arrangement for property refinancing transactions. The HKMA also collaborated with other regulatory bodies to establish a regulatory framework for the sustainable development of virtual assets, streamline the sales process for investment products, and launch a new regulatory regime for trust business. During the year, the "Credit Data Platform" under the "Multiple Credit Reference Agencies" model for personal credit data was launched, along with a new mandatory background check scheme to address the phenomenon of "rolling bad apples." In addition, in response to travel restrictions imposed due to the pandemic, the HKMA facilitated measures to help customers reactivate their bank accounts.

In light of the latest assessment of Hong Kong’s money laundering and terrorist financing risks, the HKMA and banks, through public-private partnerships (including the Anti-Fraud and Anti-Money Laundering Intelligence Task Force), strengthened Hong Kong’s ecosystem for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, and enhanced responses to fraud. The HKMA also worked with strategic partners to better understand and effectively manage the risks and instabilities arising from an increasingly complex geopolitical environment. Through the "AML Regtech Lab" series, the HKMA further promoted the use of data and technology in the industry, while accelerating the adoption of regulatory technology in its own anti-money laundering efforts. Internationally, the HKMA actively participated in the work of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF).

In 2022, significant progress was made locally in implementing international regulatory standards, such as capital adequacy and disclosure standards. In addition, the HKMA made substantial efforts to enhance the industry’s soft power, including collaborating with the banking sector to build a sustainable talent pool and upskilling existing practitioners. Throughout the year, the HKMA worked closely with the banking industry to improve and streamline regulatory policies and procedures.

The HKMA also continued to advance work at both local and international levels to ensure that Hong Kong has a credible resolution mechanism. Specific initiatives included formulating new resolution standards, conducting regional crisis simulation exercises, and establishing a new layer of loss-absorbing capacity resources at all locally systemically important banks, marking a milestone in enhancing the feasibility of resolution by the HKMA.

# Objectives

One of the HKMA’s overall objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this goal relies on establishing and maintaining a highly resilient financial system capable of providing the critical financial services required by Hong Kong’s economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the banking system through their operations, or, in extreme cases, by failing in a disorderly manner. As the regulatory authority, the Monetary Authority plays a vital role in safeguarding financial stability, ensuring that banks are able to withstand shocks and recover from crises, ultimately helping to prevent failures. The Monetary Authority is responsible for the prudential supervision of banks and for authorizing licensed banks, restricted license banks, and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively referred to as "authorized institutions").

Hong Kong’s prudential supervisory regime is not designed to ensure "zero risk." As one of the resolution authorities, the Monetary Authority strives to ensure that, should an authorized institution become non-viable, its failure can be managed in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution regime, under which the Monetary Authority acts as the resolution authority for authorized institutions (and other types of institutions). Implementing Hong Kong’s resolution regime requires the formulation of resolution rules and policy standards, resolution planning to remove impediments to the resolvability of authorized institutions, and the development of the HKMA’s operational capability to resolve failing authorized institutions. To effectively carry out these tasks, the HKMA adopts an internationally consistent and coordinated approach.

The Monetary Authority is also responsible for designating and overseeing certain financial market infrastructures. The HKMA’s oversight of financial market infrastructures aims to promote their overall safety and efficiency, control systemic risk, and enhance transparency. Strengthening the resilience of financial market infrastructures helps safeguard Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, preventing disruptions in their operations from affecting overall stability.

# Overview of Supervisory Work

In 2022, the HKMA conducted a total of 183 off-site reviews, covering a wide range of areas including CAMEL assessments, corporate governance, risk management, and the adoption of fintech by authorized institutions. To further strengthen the risk governance of authorized institutions, the HKMA held 36 meetings with the boards of directors, independent non-executive directors, or board committees of authorized institutions, and 38 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site reviews, the HKMA also conducts regular on-site examinations of the various business operations of authorized institutions. From a prudential supervision perspective, credit risk management remains one of the primary supervisory focuses. At the same time, as banks increasingly adopt technology, operational risk and technology risk management have become another key area of supervision. With the rapid development of green and sustainable banking in Hong Kong, the HKMA has also conducted a round of thematic reviews focusing on climate risk management. In terms of conduct supervision, the HKMA carries out on-site inspections of authorized institutions’ securities, investment products, insurance, and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) related businesses, supplemented by thematic assessments to review areas assessed as higher risk.

Table 1 provides an overview of the HKMA’s supervisory work in 2022.

Table 1: Overview of Supervisory Work

# Credit Risk

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

In 2022, total loans decreased by 3.0%, compared to an increase of 3.8% in 2021. Table 2 sets out the growth of various types of loans and advances. Mainland-related loans also declined by 4.4% to HKD 4,522 billion in 2022 (see Table 3).

During the year, the banking system faced challenges and shocks from various sources, including the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, escalating geopolitical tensions, aggressive interest rate hikes by major central banks, and the deteriorating financial conditions of some Mainland property developers. Despite these challenges, the banking system remained stable and sound.

The asset quality of the banking system deteriorated during the year but remained at a healthy level. The classified loan ratio of the banking sector was 1.38% at the end of 2022, up from 0.89% at the end of 2021. The classified loan ratio for Mainland-related loans rose from 0.89% a year earlier to 2.21%.

During the year, the HKMA enhanced both the breadth and depth of its risk monitoring and maintained close communication with authorized institutions to enable timely assessment of economic and market conditions, as well as the risk management measures of authorized institutions. Overall credit risk faced by the banking system remained manageable. The HKMA’s debt repayment stress test results indicated that the banking system continued to maintain adequate capital buffers and could withstand extreme stress.

The HKMA conducted thematic assessments during the year to review the credit risk management of authorized institutions, focusing on asset quality, risk exposures to more vulnerable sectors, credit risk in overseas branches, and secured lending to private banking and wealth management clients.

On the other hand, in a challenging macroeconomic environment, an increasing number of corporates are facing financial difficulties. The HKMA encourages authorized institutions to handle cases of corporate repayment difficulties in accordance with the principles set out in the Hong Kong Corporate Financial Difficulty Handling Code, thereby enabling individual authorized institutions to coordinate and cooperate from the perspective of the collective interests of the lending institutions involved.

Table 3: Growth of Mainland-related Loans

# Alleviating Customers’ Liquidity Pressure

In view of the impact of the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, coupled with the still complex and volatile external and local economic outlook, the HKMA, together with the Banking Sector SME Lending Coordination Mechanism, extended the Pre-approved Principal Payment Holiday Scheme to the end of July 2023. In addition, the scheme introduced and subsequently enhanced certain principal repayment options to help customers prepare for the eventual resumption of normal repayments.

As at the end of 2022, banks had approved over 108,000 cases of loan extensions and other support measures for corporate customers, involving more than HKD 1.1 trillion. For individual customers, banks also approved over 81,000 cases of residential mortgage principal payment holidays and other emergency personal loans, involving more than HKD 65 billion.

# Property Mortgage Loans

Since 2009, the HKMA has introduced several rounds of countercyclical macroprudential measures, which have strengthened banks’ risk management and enhanced the Hong Kong banking system’s resilience to a potential reversal in the local property market. The average loan-to-value ratio of newly approved residential mortgage loans was 57% in December 2022, compared to 64% before the first round of countercyclical measures was introduced in September 2009. The average debt service-to-income ratio of new mortgages remained low, at 39% in December 2022, compared to 41% when the cap was first introduced in August 2010 (see Figure 1).

In September, the HKMA lowered the assumed interest rate increase in the mortgage stress test from 300 basis points to 200 basis points. In making this decision, the HKMA took into account the current interest rate environment and the trend of mortgage rates relative to their long-term historical average. The HKMA considers that this level is sufficient to ensure that banks’ mortgage business risks are properly managed.

Figure 1: Average Loan-to-Value Ratio and Debt Service-to-Income Ratio of Newly Approved Residential Mortgage Loans

# Operational and Technology Risk

Over the past year, the HKMA introduced a number of measures to strengthen the operational resilience of the banking system. These measures included the issuance in May of a new module in the Supervisory Policy Manual on "Operational Resilience," which sets out the HKMA’s expectations for the governance and control frameworks that authorized institutions should maintain to ensure operational resilience. Two industry dialogues were also held to enhance industry understanding of the new standards and to facilitate experience sharing within the sector (see Illustration 1).

The HKMA also provided detailed supervisory guidance on specific areas of bank operations, including customer data protection, payment system operations, cloud computing, payment card security, and defenses against distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.

In response to the ever-evolving cyber threats, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has promoted the adoption of robust triple data backup arrangements by banks, monitored the progress of authorized institutions in implementing the "Cyber Defense Assessment Framework" 2.0, and assessed banks' capabilities in countering supply chain attacks, all with the aim of enhancing the cyber defense capabilities of the banking system.

In light of the significant increase in phishing scams and other online fraud risks, the HKMA and the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB) jointly launched a new large-scale promotional campaign in September themed "Keep an eye on your digital key, think twice before clicking any link!" to raise public awareness of prevention. In July, the HKMA also co-hosted a workshop with the Hong Kong Police Force to brief banks on the latest tactics used by fraudsters.

Poster for the promotional campaign themed "Keep an eye on your digital key, think twice before clicking any link!"

Figure 1: Industry Dialogue – "Journey Towards Operational Resilience"

# Liquidity and Market Risk

In the face of increased market volatility resulting from further monetary tightening by major economies, the HKMA has strengthened its monitoring of banks' market and liquidity risk exposures. The HKMA has conducted reviews to assess whether authorized institutions' liquidity risk management is adequate, with a focus on the diversification of funding sources and the systems and controls for intra-group liquidity risk management. In addition, the HKMA has also conducted reviews to evaluate the effectiveness of authorized institutions' market risk management frameworks and treasury business controls.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局在2022年多管齊下，在提升香港作為具全球競爭力的國際金融中心的地位方面取得重要進展。

「國際金融領袖投資峰會」舉辦成功，吸引來自約120間環球金融機構超過200位國際及區內領袖參加，不僅鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，更製造正面的漣漪效應。

在鞏固香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐方面，多個範疇均取得理想進展，包括優化金管局與中國人民銀行之間現有的貨幣互換協議，以及金管局的人民幣流動資金安排，確保有足夠人民幣流動性，協助進一步推進離岸人民幣產品及市場發展；與中國人民銀行和證券及期貨事務監察委員會聯合宣布開展「互換通」；與證券及期貨事務監察委員會和香港交易及結算所有限公司合作推出雙櫃台莊家機制，推動人民幣計價股票在香港交易；以及金管局推出多年期計劃，進一步優化金融市場基建及發展債務工具中央結算系統成為亞洲區主要的國際中央證券託管平台。受惠於充足的人民幣流動性，並憑藉世界級的市場基建及內地與香港之間各個互聯互通機制，香港已成為內地資金進入國際市場及國際投資者投資於快速增長的內地市場的首選平台。

金管局在加強香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、企業財資中心，以及綠色和可持續金融等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家認識香港穩健的金融體系及其帶來的前景。

與此同時，金管局繼續推行「金融科技2025」策略，促進金融業界更廣泛採用金融科技全面鞏固香港的金融科技樞紐地位。快速支付系統「轉數快」繼續穩步增長，登記數目在3月份突破1,000萬個，每日平均交易量亦在9月份超越100萬宗。

金管局繼續積極參與國際及區內的央行及監管組織，對維持金融穩定及促進市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

# 概覽

金管局繼續主動提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。於11月，金管局舉辦「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，落實財政司司長在《2022至23年度財政預算案》宣布的計劃。峰會為期3日，雲集國際金融業界翹楚，就如何在各項不確定因素下把握機遇分享各自獨到的觀點。是項活動獲得極大迴響，吸引超過200位來自約120個國際金融機構的重量級嘉賓參加，充分體現全球金融界對香港的支持。

香港進一步鞏固其作為離岸人民幣樞紐的地位，年內離岸人民幣業務穩健增長。香港在促進內地與國際金融市場之間的資金流方面發揮關鍵作用，香港與內地間的互聯互通機制被公認為國際投資者進入在岸資本市場及內地投資者配置離岸資產的首選渠道。在2022年，債券通「北向通」成交額佔境外投資者在中國銀行間債券市場整體成交額的61%。債券通「南向通」及「跨境理財通」自2021年開通以來一直運作暢順。金管局與中國人民銀行（人民銀行）和證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）聯合宣布開展「互換通」，把香港與內地的金融合作進一步擴展至衍生品市場，並強化了香港作為主要離岸人民幣業務樞紐及風險管理中心的地位。金管局與人民銀行之間現有的貨幣互換協議於7月優化，是加強香港作為離岸人民幣業務樞紐的另一重要里程碑。

為在香港提供更多元的人民幣計價產品，由金管局、證監會與香港交易及結算所有限公司（港交所）組成的工作小組完成擴大人民幣在港股市場交易中的使用的可行性研究。工作小組已展開籌備工作，包括推出雙櫃台莊家機制，以優化港幣及人民幣雙櫃台股票的交易機制。

金管局繼續致力提升香港金融平台的競爭力。具體而言，為增加香港作為首選基金管理中心的吸引力，金管局與政府及金融業緊密合作，締造更便利的稅務及監管環境。在推動香港債券市場創新，以及鞏固香港作為區內綠色和可持續金融樞紐的地位方面，亦取得重大進展。與此同時，金管局加強市場推廣，向海外及內地持份者介紹香港的金融服務。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室繼續與各銀行部門聯手實施「金融科技2025」策略，促進業界廣泛採用金融科技，並提升香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位。年內推行的主要措施包括：
- 促進合規科技應用及進行金融科技應用評估；
- 推動批發層面央行數碼貨幣的工作，致力改善跨境支付；
- 加深在香港發行零售層面央行數碼貨幣（即「數碼港元」或e-HKD）的研究；
- 推出「商業數據通」；
- 加強人才培育；
- 善用資源政策支持金融科技生態圈；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；及
- 推動更廣泛使用快速支付系統「轉數快」。

金融基建的可靠及有效運作，是鞏固香港作為主要國際金融中心地位的關鍵。在2022年，處理銀行同業交易的4個即時支付結算系統（RTGS系統）、債務工具中央結算系統(CMU)及香港交易資料儲存庫均達到100%2的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。債券通「北向通」及「南向通」的交收服務維持暢順。年底時存放在CMU系統的債券中，未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額為12,075億港元，其他債券的未償還總額增至相當於15,733億港元，是2013年以來最高水平。

「轉數快」使用量在2022年繼續增長。截至2022年底共有1,148萬個登記，每日平均交易量較2021年上升40%。除個人對個人支付及商業支付穩步增長外，透過「轉數快」繳付政府帳單、支付予商戶及為儲值支付工具電子錢包或銀行帳戶增值持續增加，是帶動「轉數快」交易量顯著增長的主要原因。

為促進本地零售支付業的安全及效率，金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）監察6個指定零售支付系統，並監管17個持牌儲值支付工具（其中4個由持牌銀行發行）。年內為繼續協助政府順利實施消費券計劃，金管局協調及促進相關政府部門與就計劃獲委任的儲值支付工具持牌人之間的溝通及合作。

金管局在2023年1月發布加密資產和穩定幣討論文件的總結，歸納就討論文件收集到的意見和金管局的回應。總結文件確認金管局將會以風險為本和靈活的方式監管穩定幣，並闡述預期的監管範圍、主要的監管要求及下一步的工作。

在國際層面，金管局積極參與中央銀行領域的事務，在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。自2018年起，金管局在東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)3轄下金融市場工作小組連任三屆主席。此外，金管局擔任巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組，以及金融穩定理事會轄下非銀行監察專家小組與金融創新網絡的聯席主席，另又領導金融穩定理事會轄下監察金融基準過渡相關監管事項的進度及作出跟進的小組。

# 2022年回顧

# 國際金融領袖投資峰會

「國際金融領袖投資峰會」於11月1日至3日舉行

繼財政司司長在《2022至23年度財政預算案》宣布，金管局於11月舉辦「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期3日，反響熱烈，匯聚26位金融業界翹楚就應對經濟、金融、科技及地緣政治不穩定因素，以及如何把握當中的機遇分享獨到觀點和想法。峰會共有超過200位來自約120間全球金融機構的參加者，當中超過40間機構均由集團董事長或行政總裁親自出席。參與峰會的機構不乏位列全球最大的銀行、證券、資產管理、主權財富基金、私募股權與風險投資、對冲基金及保險公司等金融界別。

峰會向全球發出明確訊息，表明香港已經一切復常；全球金融領袖可以親身感受香港獨有的韌性和活力並了解發展亞洲業務的過程中香港可以提供的機遇。

# 香港作為進入內地的主要門戶及全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐

香港致力鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位，包括增強離岸流動性、進一步加強與內地金融市場的聯通，以及提升金融市場基建。年內人民幣業務，包括銀行存款、貿易結算、支付及離岸債券發行，繼續錄得穩健增長。在增強流動性、產品開發及擴大互聯互通機制方面，取得令人鼓舞的進展及成績。2022年國際結算銀行三年一度的外匯及衍生工具市場成交額調查結果，再次確認香港作為人民幣外匯中心的領先地位。

債券通「北向通」繼續是國際投資者透過香港的市場基建及金融服務投資內地債券市場的主要渠道。債券通「北向通」於2022年的平均每日成交額達322億元人民幣（較2021年增加25%），佔境外投資者於中國銀行間債券市場整體成交額的61%。

債券通「北向通」於7月份推出技術優化措施，包括將投資者參與境內債券一級市場發行的流程電子化及降低服務費。這些市場為本的優化措施提高債券通「北向通」的運作效率，亦降低投資者的交易成本。

為完善債券通「北向通」的配套，並便利國際投資者管理內地債券投資相關的利率風險，香港與內地於7月宣布開展兩地利率互換市場互聯互通合作（「互換通」）。「互換通」初期會先開通北向交易，讓國際投資者透過香港與內地基礎設施機構之間的連接交易內地的利率互換產品，從而強化香港作為風險管理中心的地位。「互換通」籌備工作正在有序推進，以期盡快開通北向交易。金管局會繼續聯同有關當局及機構探索提供更多元化的風險管理工具，包括推出離岸國債期貨，進一步支持國際投資者投資內地債券市場。

債券通「南向通」於2021年開通以來市場反應正面，運作暢順，交易涵蓋可在香港市場買賣並以多種貨幣計價的主要債券產品。「南向通」促進了離岸人民幣市場的發展，尤其人民幣計價債務工具發行的顯著增長。金管局正與內地有關當局緊密合作，研究優化債券通「南向通」，促進香港債券市場的多元發展。

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre

In 2022, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) adopted a multi-pronged approach and made significant progress in enhancing Hong Kong’s position as a globally competitive international financial centre.

The successful hosting of the "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit" attracted over 200 international and regional leaders from around 120 global financial institutions. This not only consolidated Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre but also generated a positive ripple effect.

Significant progress was made in consolidating Hong Kong’s role as a global offshore RMB business hub across multiple areas. These included optimizing the existing currency swap agreement between the HKMA and the People’s Bank of China (PBOC), as well as the HKMA’s RMB liquidity arrangements, ensuring sufficient RMB liquidity to further promote the development of offshore RMB products and markets; jointly announcing the launch of "Swap Connect" with the PBOC and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC); collaborating with the SFC and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) to introduce a dual-counter market maker mechanism to facilitate RMB-denominated stock trading in Hong Kong; and launching a multi-year plan to further enhance financial market infrastructure and develop the Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU) into a major international central securities depository platform in Asia. Benefiting from ample RMB liquidity, world-class market infrastructure, and various mutual market access mechanisms between the Mainland and Hong Kong, the city has become the preferred platform for Mainland funds entering international markets and for international investors seeking exposure to the rapidly growing Mainland market.

The HKMA also made good progress in strengthening the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, corporate treasury centres, as well as green and sustainable finance. To promote Hong Kong’s financial services, the HKMA stepped up market outreach to overseas and Mainland stakeholders, raising awareness of Hong Kong’s robust financial system and its promising prospects.

At the same time, the HKMA continued to implement the "Fintech 2025" strategy, fostering broader adoption of fintech in the financial sector to fully consolidate Hong Kong’s position as a fintech hub. The Faster Payment System (FPS) continued its steady growth, with registrations surpassing 10 million in March and average daily transaction volumes exceeding 1 million in September.

The HKMA remained actively engaged in international and regional central banking and regulatory organizations, contributing to global efforts to maintain financial stability and promote market development.

# Overview

The HKMA continued to proactively enhance Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial centre. In November, the HKMA hosted the "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit," implementing the plan announced by the Financial Secretary in the 2022-23 Budget. The three-day summit brought together leading figures from the international financial sector to share unique perspectives on seizing opportunities amid various uncertainties. The event received an enthusiastic response, attracting over 200 distinguished guests from around 120 international financial institutions, fully reflecting the global financial community’s support for Hong Kong.

Hong Kong further consolidated its position as an offshore RMB hub, with robust growth in offshore RMB business during the year. The city played a key role in facilitating capital flows between Mainland and international financial markets, with mutual market access mechanisms between Hong Kong and the Mainland recognized as the preferred channels for international investors entering onshore capital markets and for Mainland investors allocating to offshore assets. In 2022, Bond Connect (Northbound) accounted for 61% of total trading volume by overseas investors in China’s interbank bond market. Bond Connect (Southbound) and Wealth Management Connect have both operated smoothly since their launch in 2021. The HKMA, together with the PBOC and the SFC, jointly announced the launch of "Swap Connect," further expanding financial cooperation between Hong Kong and the Mainland into the derivatives market and strengthening Hong Kong’s role as a major offshore RMB business hub and risk management centre. The optimization of the existing currency swap agreement between the HKMA and the PBOC in July marked another important milestone in reinforcing Hong Kong’s status as an offshore RMB business hub.

To provide a more diversified range of RMB-denominated products in Hong Kong, a working group comprising the HKMA, the SFC, and HKEX completed a feasibility study on expanding the use of RMB in the Hong Kong stock market. The group has commenced preparatory work, including the introduction of a dual-counter market maker mechanism to optimize trading in dual-currency (HKD and RMB) stocks.

The HKMA remains committed to enhancing the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform. Specifically, to increase Hong Kong’s attractiveness as a preferred fund management centre, the HKMA has worked closely with the government and the financial industry to create a more facilitative tax and regulatory environment. Significant progress has also been made in promoting innovation in Hong Kong’s bond market and consolidating the city’s position as a regional hub for green and sustainable finance. Meanwhile, the HKMA has intensified market promotion efforts to introduce Hong Kong’s financial services to overseas and Mainland stakeholders.

The HKMA Fintech Facilitation Office continued to collaborate with various banking sectors to implement the "Fintech 2025" strategy, promoting the widespread adoption of fintech within the industry and enhancing Hong Kong's position as a fintech hub in Asia. Major initiatives launched during the year included:
- Promoting the application of Regtech and conducting fintech adoption assessments;
- Advancing work on wholesale central bank digital currency (CBDC) to improve cross-border payments;
- Deepening research on the issuance of retail CBDC in Hong Kong (i.e., the "digital Hong Kong dollar" or e-HKD);
- Launching the Commercial Data Interchange (CDI);
- Strengthening talent development;
- Leveraging policy resources to support the fintech ecosystem;
- Enhancing cross-border fintech cooperation; and
- Promoting broader use of the Faster Payment System (FPS).

The reliable and efficient operation of financial infrastructure is key to consolidating Hong Kong's status as a major international financial centre. In 2022, the four real-time gross settlement (RTGS) systems for interbank transactions, the Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU), and the Hong Kong Trade Repository all achieved 100% system availability, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Settlement services for Bond Connect's Northbound and Southbound channels remained smooth. By year-end, the outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Bills and Notes held in the CMU system stood at HK$1,207.5 billion, while the outstanding amount of other bonds increased to HK$1,573.3 billion, the highest level since 2013.

Usage of FPS continued to grow in 2022. As of end-2022, there were 11.48 million registrations, with the average daily transaction volume up 40% compared to 2021. In addition to steady growth in person-to-person and business payments, the use of FPS for paying government bills, merchant payments, and topping up stored value facility (SVF) e-wallets or bank accounts continued to increase, which was the main driver of the significant growth in FPS transaction volume.

To promote the safety and efficiency of the local retail payment industry, the HKMA supervises six designated retail payment systems and regulates 17 licensed SVFs (of which four are issued by licensed banks) under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the "Payment Ordinance"). During the year, to continue supporting the smooth implementation of the government's consumption voucher scheme, the HKMA coordinated and facilitated communication and cooperation between relevant government departments and the SVF licensees appointed for the scheme.

In January 2023, the HKMA published a summary of the discussion paper on crypto-assets and stablecoins, consolidating the feedback received and the HKMA's responses. The summary confirmed that the HKMA will regulate stablecoins in a risk-based and flexible manner, and outlined the expected regulatory scope, key requirements, and next steps.

At the international level, the HKMA actively participated in central banking affairs and played a leadership role in various regional and international committees. Since 2018, the HKMA has served three consecutive terms as Chair of the EMEAP Financial Markets Working Group. In addition, the HKMA co-chairs the Policy and Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, as well as the Non-bank Monitoring Experts Group and the Financial Innovation Network under the Financial Stability Board. The HKMA also leads the group responsible for monitoring and following up on regulatory matters related to the transition of financial benchmarks under the Financial Stability Board.

# 2022 Review

# Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit

The "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit" was held from November 1 to 3.

Following the announcement by the Financial Secretary in the 2022-23 Budget, the HKMA hosted the "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit" in November. The three-day summit received an enthusiastic response, bringing together 26 leading figures in the financial industry to share unique insights and perspectives on addressing economic, financial, technological, and geopolitical uncertainties, as well as how to seize the opportunities arising from them. The summit attracted over 200 participants from around 120 global financial institutions, with more than 40 institutions represented by their group chairmen or chief executive officers. Participating institutions included some of the world's largest banks, securities firms, asset managers, sovereign wealth funds, private equity and venture capital firms, hedge funds, and insurance companies.

The summit sent a clear message to the world that Hong Kong has fully returned to normal. Global financial leaders were able to experience first-hand Hong Kong's unique resilience and vibrancy, and to understand the opportunities Hong Kong offers for developing business in Asia.

# Hong Kong as the Primary Gateway to Mainland China and the Global Offshore RMB Business Hub

Hong Kong is committed to consolidating its position as the global offshore RMB business hub, including enhancing offshore liquidity, further strengthening connectivity with Mainland financial markets, and upgrading financial market infrastructure. During the year, RMB business—including bank deposits, trade settlement, payments, and offshore bond issuance—continued to record steady growth. Encouraging progress and results were achieved in enhancing liquidity, product development, and expanding mutual market access mechanisms. The 2022 triennial survey of foreign exchange and derivatives market turnover by the Bank for International Settlements once again confirmed Hong Kong's leading position as an RMB foreign exchange centre.

Bond Connect Northbound continued to be the main channel for international investors to access the Mainland bond market through Hong Kong's market infrastructure and financial services. In 2022, the average daily turnover of Bond Connect Northbound reached RMB 32.2 billion (an increase of 25% over 2021), accounting for 61% of the total turnover by overseas investors in the China interbank bond market.

In July, Bond Connect (Northbound) introduced technical enhancements, including the digitization of the process for investors to participate in the primary market issuance of onshore bonds and the reduction of service fees. These market-based optimization measures have improved the operational efficiency of Bond Connect (Northbound) and reduced transaction costs for investors.

To further enhance the supporting measures for Bond Connect (Northbound) and facilitate international investors in managing interest rate risks associated with their investments in Mainland bonds, Hong Kong and the Mainland announced in July the launch of mutual access between the two interest rate swap markets ("Swap Connect"). Swap Connect will initially open with Northbound trading, allowing international investors to trade Mainland interest rate swap products through the connectivity between Hong Kong and Mainland infrastructure institutions, thereby strengthening Hong Kong's position as a risk management centre. Preparatory work for Swap Connect is progressing in an orderly manner, with the aim of launching Northbound trading as soon as possible. The HKMA will continue to work with relevant authorities and institutions to explore the provision of more diversified risk management tools, including the introduction of offshore government bond futures, to further support international investors in accessing the Mainland bond market.

Since its launch in 2021, Bond Connect (Southbound) has received a positive market response and has operated smoothly, with transactions covering major bond products that can be traded in the Hong Kong market and denominated in multiple currencies. Southbound Bond Connect has promoted the development of the offshore RMB market, particularly the significant growth in the issuance of RMB-denominated debt instruments. The HKMA is working closely with Mainland authorities to study the optimization of Bond Connect (Southbound) and to promote the diversified development of Hong Kong's bond market.

# 儲備管理

2022年的投資環境異常動盪，多種資產類別的價格同時下挫，不僅打破同時持有股票與債券可產生緩減風險作用的傳統投資智慧，更成為近半世紀以來唯一一次股票、債券及主要非美元貨幣匯兌同時錄得負回報的一年。在如此惡劣的投資環境下，外匯基金在2022年錄得投資回報率負4.5%。與年內大部分多元資產基金蒙受重大虧損的情況相比，外匯基金的表現反映金管局的多元化長期資產配置，以及因應外圍最新局勢變化而作出的防禦性部署及戰略性調整，有效減低市場風暴帶來的衝擊。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(i) 保障資本；
(ii) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(iii) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(iv) 在符合上述(i)至(iii)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障外匯基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合架構及目標資產配置中反映（圖示1）。

圖示1 外匯基金的投資組合類別

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員經濟體的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的目標資產配置與其他資產類別的配置，按審慎的風險管理原則及資產組合多元化策略一起制定。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的回報掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重於2022年約為35：65。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責外匯基金的投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約70%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分內部管理的投資組合包括不同的環球定息市場投資，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，風險管理的重要性不言而喻。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線，以實施有效的風險管理及管治。金管局定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），而風險管理程序的設置為外匯基金的策略性規劃及多元化投資提供穩健的框架。

# 負責任投資

金管局相信透過適度強調負責任投資及考慮各項投資的可持續長期表現，可更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動涉及的環境、社會及管治(ESG)相關風險。當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，金管局一般會按既定指導性原則優先考慮ESG投資，並已將ESG因素併入外匯基金的公開市場及私募市場的投資管理過程中。有關金管局的負責任投資框架及落實情況，詳見《二零二二年可持續發展報告》之「負責任投資」一章。

# 外匯基金的表現

# 2022 年的金融市場

2022年環球金融市場異常波動，債市及股市分別累計下跌16.2%及19.8%，跌幅顯著。

受累於全球通脹飆升、緊縮貨幣政策及經濟增長放緩，年內主要股市指數大幅下挫。儘管環球股市因市場出現通脹及利率見頂的憧憬而於年末稍作反彈，年內美國標準普爾500指數仍下跌19.4%，香港恒生指數則下跌15.5%。

由於各國央行進取加息以對抗通脹，觸發主要市場國債收益率持續飆升。美國10年期國債收益率從2022年初的1.63%一直攀升，至第4季升穿4%，達2008年以來最高水平。美國國債收益率曲線自年中開始已出現倒掛，幅度不斷擴大，加深市場對經濟衰退的憂慮。

貨幣市場方面，在美國聯邦儲備局連續加息帶動下，美元在2022年大幅走強。其他主要貨幣，包括歐元、英鎊、日圓及人民幣兌美元匯率大幅貶值，其中英鎊及日圓兌美元分別貶值10.7%及12.2%。

# Reserve Management

The investment environment in 2022 was exceptionally volatile, with prices across multiple asset classes declining simultaneously. This not only shattered the traditional investment wisdom that holding both equities and bonds can provide risk mitigation, but also marked the only year in nearly half a century in which equities, bonds, and major non-US dollar currencies all recorded negative returns. In such an adverse investment environment, the Exchange Fund recorded an investment return of -4.5% in 2022. Compared to the significant losses suffered by most multi-asset funds during the year, the performance of the Exchange Fund reflects the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) diversified long-term asset allocation, as well as its defensive deployment and strategic adjustments in response to the latest external developments, which effectively reduced the impact of market turmoil.

# The Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to affect, either directly or indirectly, the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar. It may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre. The HKMA, under the authority delegated by the Financial Secretary and in accordance with the terms of such delegation, is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the use and investment management of the Exchange Fund.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has set the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(i) Capital preservation;
(ii) Ensuring that the entire monetary base is at all times fully backed by highly liquid US dollar assets;
(iii) Ensuring sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(iv) Subject to (i) to (iii) above, seeking to maximize investment returns to preserve the long-term purchasing power of the Exchange Fund.

These objectives comprehensively address the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and are reflected in the portfolio structure and target asset allocation of the Fund (see Diagram 1).

Diagram 1: Types of Exchange Fund Investment Portfolios

Broadly, the Exchange Fund is divided into two main portfolios: the Backing Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Backing Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets to provide full backing for the monetary base as required under the currency board system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in the bond and equity markets of member economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), with the aim of preserving asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risk and enhance medium- to long-term returns, the HKMA has prudently and progressively allocated part of the Exchange Fund’s assets to a more diversified range of asset classes, including emerging market and Mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging market and Mainland bonds and equities are held under the Investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held under the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The target asset allocation of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio, together with the allocation to other asset classes, is determined in accordance with prudent risk management principles and a diversification strategy.

The Strategic Portfolio was established in 2007 and has since held shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) acquired by the Exchange Fund for strategic purposes. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, its performance is not included in the evaluation of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance.

# Deposits Placed with the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund from time to time accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory bodies. The interest rates on these deposits are generally linked to the performance of the Investment Portfolio, with the Future Fund being a major exception. The interest rate on Future Fund deposits is linked to the returns of both the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio, with the actual rate depending on the weighting of each portfolio. In 2022, the weighting of the Future Fund in the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was approximately 35:65.

# Investment Process

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on both strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation is reflected in the investment benchmark, which represents the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund may adopt to achieve its investment objectives. The strategic allocation serves as a guideline, while tactical asset allocation is employed to seek returns in excess of the benchmark. As a result, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocations is referred to as the "tactical deviation." The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limit. The HKMA is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and set the permissible range for tactical deviation. Portfolio managers may manage positions within the permissible range of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market movements.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Exchange Fund Investment Office of the HKMA is responsible for the investment and related risk management functions of the Exchange Fund. Staff of the office directly manage about 70% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the entire Backing Portfolio and part of the Investment Portfolio. The internally managed portion of the Investment Portfolio includes various global fixed income market investments, and macro risk management strategies for the Exchange Fund are implemented through derivative instruments.

# External Investment Managers

In addition to managing assets internally, the HKMA also employs external investment managers to manage about 30% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special asset classes. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to leverage the best professional investment expertise available in the market for the Exchange Fund, to achieve sustainable returns, and to enable the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as to gain market insights and specialized investment knowledge.

Expenditures related to the engagement of external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding tax, and other taxes. These expenses vary from year to year, primarily influenced by market factors.

# Risk Management and Monitoring

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, the importance of risk management is self-evident. The HKMA has established stringent control measures and investment guidelines for portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and has implemented rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. The HKMA has instituted a three lines of defense framework for investment-related activities to ensure effective risk management and governance. The HKMA regularly monitors major categories of investment risk, including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks. The risk management procedures provide a robust framework for the strategic planning and diversified investment of the Exchange Fund.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA believes that by appropriately emphasizing responsible investment and considering the sustainable long-term performance of each investment, the investment objectives of the Exchange Fund can be achieved more effectively, while reducing environment, social, and governance (ESG) risks associated with investment activities. When the risk-adjusted long-term returns of ESG investments are comparable to those of other investment projects, the HKMA generally gives priority to ESG investments in accordance with established guiding principles, and has incorporated ESG factors into the investment management processes for both public and private markets of the Exchange Fund. For details on the HKMA’s responsible investment framework and its implementation, please refer to the "Responsible Investment" chapter in the 2022 Sustainability Report.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2022

Global financial markets were exceptionally volatile in 2022, with the bond and equity markets recording cumulative declines of 16.2% and 19.8% respectively, both significant drops.

Major stock indices fell sharply during the year, weighed down by surging global inflation, tight monetary policy, and slowing economic growth. Although global equity markets rebounded slightly towards the end of the year on hopes that inflation and interest rates had peaked, the S&P 500 Index still declined by 19.4% for the year, while the Hang Seng Index fell by 15.5%.

As central banks around the world aggressively raised interest rates to combat inflation, yields on major government bonds surged. The yield on the US 10-year Treasury note climbed from 1.63% at the beginning of 2022 to over 4% in the fourth quarter, reaching its highest level since 2008. The US Treasury yield curve became inverted from mid-year onwards, with the inversion deepening and heightening market concerns over a potential economic recession.

In the currency markets, the US dollar strengthened significantly in 2022, driven by consecutive rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Other major currencies, including the euro, pound sterling, Japanese yen, and renminbi, depreciated sharply against the US dollar, with the pound and yen depreciating by 10.7% and 12.2% respectively.

# 風險管理

管理貨幣及銀行體系的風險是金管局最重要的工作之一。風險管理除了體現於策略制定外，亦應用於日常運作層面。金管局的風險管理框架設有兩個高層次委員會，即宏觀監察委員會及風險委員會；兩者均由金管局總裁擔任主席。

宏觀監察委員會的職權範圍如下：
- 識別香港貨幣及金融體系所面對的潛在風險與威脅，並商討可行對策；
- 檢討現行貨幣及金融體系的風險管理措施，識別可能存在的漏洞，並確保措施完善；及
- 鼓勵跨部門分享宏觀監察資訊，從而提高金管局的宏觀監察能力。

風險委員會的職權範圍如下：
- 識別金管局面對的潛在風險及威脅，並制定策略以減輕有關影響；
- 檢討各部門現行的風險管理制度，識別可能存在的漏洞及重大風險，並確保備有適當措施應付有關情況；
- 統一風險評估準則及方法，並就所識別的風險釐定資源管理的優先次序；及
- 鼓勵及加強金管局內部的風險管理文化，推動適當的授權及監控。

金管局設有一套穩健的營運風險管理框架，涵蓋機構層面及部門層面的組織架構風險。機構層面的風險泛指涉及整體機構所面對的中期風險，或需要跨部門共同應對的風險。在執行過程中，各部門需按季檢討及匯報其潛在和新興風險，以及所提出之監控措施和緩解策略，再輔以由上而下的機構風險管理模式，由各部門的管理高層識別影響較廣泛的主要風險及建議緩解措施。有關評估會經由風險委員會定期審議和決定適當的跟進行動。

# 內部審核

# Maintaining Transparency

# Media Relations and Social Media

The HKMA maintains close ties with the media to enhance transparency and increase public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2022, the HKMA organized or participated in a total of 112 physical and online events, including 8 press conferences, 11 on-site interviews, and 93 other public events. The HKMA also arranged 46 media interviews. During the year, 492 bilingual press releases were issued, and a large volume of media enquiries was handled daily.

To enhance public awareness of its key functions, the HKMA organized press conferences and media briefings for local, Mainland, and overseas media, covering topics such as Currency Board operations, green and sustainable finance, and central bank digital currency.

Various media outlets actively participated in HKMA events held in 2022, including the "International Financial Leaders' Investment Summit." The three-day summit attracted significant media attention, with over 200 journalists from 87 media organizations attending and approximately 1,000 news reports published in local, regional, and international media. In addition, live streaming was arranged for 30 media organizations.

To effectively engage the public, the HKMA operates six social media pages (including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter, WeChat, and YouTube), with over 100,000 followers. In 2022, the HKMA launched a WeChat page to reach a broader audience. The HKMA uses social media to promote major events and initiatives, such as the "International Financial Leaders' Investment Summit" and the Government Green Bond Programme, and to raise public awareness in areas such as the Linked Exchange Rate System, fintech, and fraud prevention.

# Publications

In addition to the HKMA Annual Report, the HKMA publishes two issues of the Monetary and Financial Stability Half-Yearly Report and four issues of the Quarterly Bulletin each year, and regularly updates the Monthly Statistical Bulletin, providing the latest and thematic information and analysis on Hong Kong’s currency, banking sector, and economic affairs. The HKMA also published 17 articles in "Insight," introducing key initiatives and policies and discussing matters of public concern.

The HKMA’s 2021 Annual Report received the Silver Award in the "Non-profit and Charitable Organizations" category and a Merit Award for "Environmental, Social and Governance Reporting" at the Hong Kong Management Association’s 2022 Best Annual Reports Awards.

# Institutional Website

The institutional website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 46,000 pages of information in English, Traditional Chinese, and Simplified Chinese, facilitating public access to the latest information about the HKMA. The website also contains the Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representative Offices and the Register of Securities Staff of Authorized Institutions, maintained under section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the Register of Stored Value Facility Licensees maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance.

Since 2018, the HKMA has been releasing financial data and key information from its website in phases through open application programming interfaces (open APIs). As of the end of 2022, the HKMA had launched a total of 148 sets of open APIs on its website as planned.

# Information Centre

The HKMA Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of Two International Finance Centre. It serves as an important facility for introducing the work of the HKMA to the public and enhancing public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre comprises two sections: an exhibition hall and a library. The exhibition hall uses interactive displays to introduce the work of the HKMA and the development of Hong Kong’s monetary and banking sectors; it also provides materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and financial affairs. Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library houses over 26,000 books, periodicals, and other publications covering topics such as Hong Kong’s currency, banking, finance, and central banking. In accordance with Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, the library also maintains the Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representative Offices and the Register of Securities Staff of Authorized Institutions for public inspection.

With the pandemic situation stabilizing, the Information Centre gradually resumed public guided tour services in the second half of 2022.

Following renovations, the newly refurbished library reopened to the public in March 2023.

# Community Engagement and Public Education

To maintain community engagement and enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s work, the HKMA has been organizing public education seminars since 1998. In 2022, the HKMA held online seminars that attracted over 2,200 teachers and students from 82 secondary schools. The seminars covered topics such as an introduction to the HKMA’s work, the Linked Exchange Rate System, Hong Kong banknotes, safeguarding personal digital keys, the Deposit Protection Scheme, and opportunities in the banking sector. To date, more than 65,000 participants have attended the public education seminars.

The HKMA educates and engages the public to remind them how to be smart and responsible consumers of financial services. In view of the increase in phishing scams, the HKMA launched a cross-media publicity campaign to further remind the public to beware of fraudulent hyperlinks in SMS messages and emails purportedly from banks, and to stay vigilant against other types of scams involving deposits, credit cards, and more. The HKMA also conducted radio and social media campaigns to provide tips on the smart use of credit cards, personal loans, online shopping, and other payment methods (including "buy now, pay later" products).

To help the public keep pace with developments in fintech services, the HKMA used social media and radio promotions to encourage the public to give out electronic lai see during Lunar New Year. The HKMA produced animated videos explaining open APIs and highlighting important considerations when using banking services via mobile applications of third-party service providers (such as online shopping platforms and mortgage service companies). The videos also introduced the App-to-App and Web-to-App payment features and benefits of the Faster Payment System (FPS).

Animated videos help enhance public knowledge of digital finance.

The HKMA is also committed to deepening public understanding of the financial industry and increasing young people’s interest in joining the HKMA and the sector. In newly produced interview videos, graduates of the HKMA Graduate Trainee Programme share their experiences, not only introducing the programme to prospective applicants but also enhancing their understanding of the HKMA’s work.

Graduate Trainee Programme alumni share tips on preparing for interviews.

To improve financial literacy among secondary school students, the HKMA co-organized the 8th consecutive "Hong Kong Financial Management Challenge" with several relevant organizations. This year’s theme was green and sustainable finance. Students gained new knowledge through an online quiz competition (with a record number of participants), webinars, and a design thinking competition.

Students present innovative solutions with green and sustainable elements in the design thinking competition to address personal financial management needs.

During the 2021-22 academic year, the HKMA launched the "Little Financial Planner" online parent-child financial education activity during the March special holiday and the August summer break. Through animated videos, storytelling, simple toy making, and sharing sessions with financial and early childhood education experts, kindergarten and lower primary students learned about the basics of banknotes and coins, banking and payment services, and financial literacy.

Children learn financial concepts and skills online.

# Financial Disclosure

To maintain a high level of transparency, the HKMA adopts international financial disclosure standards applicable to central banking operations, including the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards and other relevant reporting requirements (such as the International Monetary Fund’s Special Data Dissemination Standard). With the assistance of independent auditors and other accounting professionals, the Finance Division prepares the Exchange Fund financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards. In addition, the HKMA’s Annual Report provides detailed disclosure and in-depth analysis of each expenditure item and budget data.

# Accountability and Oversight

# Risk Management

Managing risks to the monetary and banking systems is one of the HKMA’s most important tasks. Risk management is reflected not only in strategic planning but also in daily operations. The HKMA’s risk management framework includes two high-level committees: the Macro Surveillance Committee and the Risk Committee, both chaired by the Chief Executive of the HKMA.

The Macro Surveillance Committee’s terms of reference are as follows:
- Identify potential risks and threats to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems and discuss possible countermeasures;
- Review existing risk management measures for the monetary and financial systems, identify possible loopholes, and ensure the adequacy of these measures; and
- Encourage cross-departmental sharing of macro surveillance information to enhance the HKMA’s macro surveillance capability.

The terms of reference of the Risk Committee are as follows:
- To identify potential risks and threats faced by the HKMA and formulate strategies to mitigate their impact;
- To review the existing risk management systems of various departments, identify possible loopholes and significant risks, and ensure that appropriate measures are in place to address such situations;
- To standardize risk assessment criteria and methodologies, and to determine resource management priorities for the identified risks; and
- To encourage and strengthen the risk management culture within the HKMA, promoting appropriate authorization and monitoring.

The HKMA has established a robust operational risk management framework that covers both institutional-level and departmental-level organizational structure risks. Institutional-level risks refer to medium-term risks faced by the organization as a whole, or risks that require cross-departmental collaboration. In practice, each department is required to review and report its potential and emerging risks, as well as the proposed control measures and mitigation strategies, on a quarterly basis. This is complemented by a top-down institutional risk management approach, whereby senior management of each department identifies major risks with broader impact and recommends mitigation measures. These assessments are regularly reviewed by the Risk Committee, which determines appropriate follow-up actions.

# Internal Audit

The Internal Audit Division independently and objectively assesses whether the HKMA’s governance, risk management, and control procedures are adequate and effective. Functionally, the division reports to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and administratively to the Chief Executive of the HKMA. The Internal Audit Division adopts a risk-based approach in conducting audits of business operations and information systems, covering all major risk areas. In 2022, the division conducted a total of 28 audits on the HKMA’s reserve management, banking supervision, monetary and financial development, information technology, and other institutional functions. The audit results indicated that the HKMA has adequate and effective control measures in place to manage the risks arising from its operations.

# 審計署署長報告

# 獨立審計師報告致財政司司長

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第179頁至281頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2022年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

我認為，該等財務報表已按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》真實而中肯地反映外匯基金及集團於2022年12月31日的財務狀況及截至該日止年度的財務表現和現金流量，並已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》（第66章）第7條下所發出的指示妥為擬備。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

關鍵審計事項是根據我的專業判斷，對截至2022年12月31日止年度財務報表的審計最為重要的事項。我對整體財務報表進行審計及形成意見時處理了這些事項，而我不會對這些事項提供單獨的意見。

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.5、2.6及38.1。

於2022年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共38,361.82億港元，金融負債共12,074.98億港元。

87%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘13%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共4,876.94億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：
- 了解不同類別金融資產及金融負債的估值程序，包括相關監控措施；
- 評價及測試監控措施，包括電腦系統的相關應用程式監控措施；
- 就金融資產及金融負債的估值、存在、權利與責任及完整性取得函證；
- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；
- 若所用估值方法的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合及有關假設是否合理，以及根據獨立來源核實參數；及
- 若所用估值方法的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.11、18及19。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2022年12月31日共值233.94億港元。集團亦於4間聯營公司及22間合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業，有關權益共值396.31億港元。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：
- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；
- 評估估值師的獨立性及資歷；及
- 評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 其他資料

金融管理專員須對其他資料負責。其他資料包括金融管理局2022年年報內的所有資料，但不包括財務報表及我的審計師報告。

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Opinion

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Commission’s auditing standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. In conducting an audit in accordance with the Audit Commission’s auditing standards, I exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. I also:
- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks; and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my opinion. I am responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the Group audit. I remain solely responsible for my audit opinion.
